- When writing machine learning code in Python, use Pytorch unless there are strong compelling reasons for using another library.

- Make sure all Python code is compatible with Python version 3.11.

parts: My github repo is not properly rendering latex. Accuracy is a basic metric that measures the proportion of correctly classified instances over the total number of instances. It is defined as: [ \text{Accuracy} = \frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN} ]  . Any way to fix this?

GitHub does not natively support LaTeX rendering within Markdown files (like `README.md`). However, there are a few ways to display LaTeX-style formulas properly:

### 1. Use a Third-Party Service (like MathJax)
You can include a link to a service like [MathJax](https://www.mathjax.org/) in your Markdown to render LaTeX.

#### Example
```markdown
<script type="text/javascript" async
  src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/mathjax/3.1.2/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js">
</script>

Accuracy is a basic metric that measures the proportion of correctly classified instances over the total number of instances. It is defined as:
\[ \text{Accuracy} = \frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN} \]
```
Inserting the above script tag should allow you to render LaTeX-style math on GitHub pages or GitHub Pages-hosted websites (but not within the GitHub Markdown preview itself).

### 2. Use Images
For README or Markdown files, you can use rendered LaTeX as an image.

#### Example:
You can use tools like [codecogs](https://www.codecogs.com/latex/eqneditor.php) or [QuickLaTeX](https://www.quicklatex.com/) to generate images for LaTeX expressions.

Once generated, you can use the following in your Markdown file:
```markdown
Accuracy is a basic metric that measures the proportion of correctly classified instances over the total number of instances. It is defined as:  
![Accuracy](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\text{Accuracy}=\frac{TP+TN}{TP+TN+FP+FN})
```

This will embed the rendered formula as an image in your GitHub README.

### 3. GitHub Pages or Jupyter Notebooks
If you are open to using [GitHub Pages](https://pages.github.com/) or working in a Jupyter Notebook, both support LaTeX rendering natively. If you host your content via GitHub Pages, you can use full LaTeX features by embedding MathJax in the HTML of your website.

Would one of these approaches work for you?
